review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

review:
If you are tempted by a low price and positive reviews - don’t be fooled. The only somewhat good thing about this game is its visuals. Well, price, achievements and trading cards if you didn’t really come to play the game. But if you did, here is a quick list of the things you will have to deal with:
[list]
    [*]Despite being called a strategy, it is just a tug-of-war flash game, where you control only the production, not the combat. The map is a corridor where your units clash, so the only “strategy” is to choose a ship you will spam.
    [*]No balance whatsoever. There are completely broken ships that annihilate enemies, and there are deadweight ships that do nothing. The same goes for faction abilities.
    [*]No real gameplay, you just spam a button and win, as the AI is just stupid even on hard. And no, there are no people in multiplayer, just check the achievements - only about 7% of people even PLAYED the game.
    [*]Obviously, no stats shown, no explanation in the UI, if you forgot what the ship does - main menu help is all you have.
    [*]No, the story is the same exact skirmish and has nothing special.
    [*]Oh, I nearly forgot that you have bonus pick-ups in this “strategy game”.
    [*]Annoying sound effects
[/list]

All those positive reviews for something that feels and plays like a flash game from 2005? You must be kidding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1688732550}
review:
Aeon Command is at face value an RTS, but really, it plays more like a simple soldier attack/tower defense game where the objective is to pump out units faster than the enemy and that's it.  For some reason the whole map is just a long thin rectangle with a player at each end, because the developer wanted this to seem like a "tug of war".  Kinda like taking a game like Deus Ex and turning it into a cover shooter.

Did RTS games need to be dumbed down? There's an upgrade tree, different units, harvesting... but all the strategy and maneuvering elements are missing.  As a result... it's just not fun. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

While there are options to change the resolution for the game, all this does is scale up the simplistic 2D art assets used to make the game, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the lacklustre 2D visuals.

The game doesn't correctly account for modern PC displays, UI scaling isn't handled correctly.  As a result of this unfortunate decision, text and UI elements don't display at a reasonable size, it's too small to be legible on most modern gaming PCs, and there's no in-game controls or options to correct this.  This can render the game unplayable for many.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

You don't have to take my word about how bad the game is, we can measure the interest in a game by how much people bothered to play it.  Aeon Command has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game absolutely failed to capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for completing the first "Alliance" tutorial campaign, trivial to achieve, but less than 10 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  That's a tiny, tiny proportion of gamers who even bothered with this.  Ouch.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this isn't consistent with the achievement stats, that show less than 10 percent of players bothered playing the game for any reasonable amount of time.  How is it possible for this game to have so many concurrent players who weren't even playing the game?  Trading cards.  Players will use card idling software to collect the cards and sell them, but this won't trigger any achievements in-game.  That tells us people only really bought this game for trading cards, and that's a damning indictment of the woeful quality.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

Aeon Command is relatively cheap at $3 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

review:
Aeon Command, bir uzay strateji oyunu ve 3 Temmuz 2014'te Bat Country Games, LLC tarafından yayınlandı. Oyunda, bir uzay gemisi filosunun komutasını ele geçiriyorsunuz ve düşman gemileriyle savaşıyorsunuz. Oyun, basit bir arayüz ve kolay öğrenme eğrisi ile taktiksel derinlik sunar. Ayrıca, oyunun özelleştirilebilir bir harita editörü de bulunuyor.

Oyunda, farklı gemilerin farklı özellikleri ve silahları var. Oyuncular, gemilerini düşmanlara karşı kullanarak onları yok etmeye çalışırken, aynı zamanda gemilerini de korumak zorundalar. Oyuncular, kaynakları doğru bir şekilde kullanarak filolarını geliştirebilir ve daha güçlü gemiler inşa edebilirler.

Aeon Command, basit ama bağımlılık yapıcı oynanışı, stratejik derinliği ve özelleştirilebilir harita editörü ile dikkat çeken bir uzay strateji oyunudur.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018600044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1094, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1094, 'last_played': 1674933293}
review:
AEON COMMAND is a simple but enjoyable strategy game where we collect resources, build starships and destroy the enemy base before it annihilates our own.  It is much like a tug-of-war or a Tower Defence game in 2D with moving units replacing stationary towers.

There are 3 campaigns featuring a different faction - Alliance, Exile or Cyborg - and although all have a variety of starships to build the campaign is essentially the same for each.

Starting off with a single command flagship, we create several collector craft which gather resources from nearby asteroids in order to fund our growing war machine.  Resources allow us to research new units - a maximum of 7 different ships are available per faction - and these in turn can have their weapon and hull ratings upgraded a maximum of 5 times each.

The top of the screen has a scanner-like radar which displays the allied flagship to the extreme left and the enemy counterpart on the far right, while all other ships are represented as moving coloured dots.  This is important to keep an eye on throughout the game and indicates how well each faction is doing by the number of units it controls.

Creating anything other than a collector automatically sends the unit heading towards the enemy flagship.  The ship will either attack (or in some cases capture) any enemies it encounters along the way and, if the unit survives to reach the enemy base will shoot at that too.  Each unit has a strength bar which depletes when damaged and destroyed ships instantly vanish and are removed from play.  Loss of the flagship ends the game.

Bear in mind that we do not control any of the units at any time and once launched, they merely fly towards the enemy flagship and initiate combat whenever they chance upon an enemy.   Units do not heal by themselves - although there are buffs we can apply if we have the necessary resources to do so during the game - and they will not even manoeuvre when under fire but often just stop and shoot back.  Thus victory often depends upon which unit is the strongest unless allies arrive to add their own firepower and turn the tide.   We are not allowed to manually group units or even plot courses for our ships.  Therefore strategy is minimal. Missions can be won simply by creating as many units as possible so that they swamp the enemy defences and break through to the flagship.

Often destroyed enemies will drop bonus parts which, in between playing campaign missions, allows us to strengthen our chosen faction up to 18 times to make our forces stronger in future missions.

Games may be played on either Easy, Medium or Hard settings and we can also tweak the SFX, music volume, full screen and resolution.  As well as the campaigns themselves we also have the option of playing skirmish games for all 3 factions or, to mix things up a bit, allowing random combinations of units per faction.  This adds to the unpredictability and strategy a little, although we soon learn what each unit can do and how it may be successfully countered.

Sadly the multiplayer option is no longer working and the game permanently stalls at the "Establishing Connection" phase, which is a pity.

Once a flagship is destroyed and the game ends we are treated to a statistics screen giving information on ships killed or lost, resources collected, researches completed, bonus parts found and overall score.

There are 18 Achievements to collect and some grind is required to acquire them all, although fortunately none are for multiplayer games so we can still gain a 100% rating.  The game has adequate sound and nice animation which rarely slows down, although the graphics are a little on the small side.  Sadly there is no zoom option to have a closer look at the action.

While I found AEON COMMAND a fun game there is nothing to keep me coming back to it now all the Achievements have been unlocked, although I will rarely play skirmish games with randomised forces.  More variety would have been nice, such as a troop carrier ship unit allowing us to land marines on enemy flagships to commandeer rather than destroy them, for instance.  The loss of multiplayer does not help either, especially as there is no chance of future DLC being made available since the game has not been updated in several years.

I would have liked to  give AEON COMMAND a Neutral rating if one had been available on STEAM due to the problems listed above but at least it proved a briefly enjoyable experience at a good price, hence the Recommended verdict.

This is an easy to understand tug of war strategy game. There isn't a lot of deviation from the subgenre's tropes. You spawn units to push the enemies back to their base and destroy it. There are some abilities you can use to influence the fights but, as is basically expected, your units fight and advance on their own. The biggest standout difference is the addition of a worker economy--you have to build vulnerable harvesters to collect resources to build your army. This is a great change, as it creates stakes for letting the enemies get too close to your side of the map. If you let their long range stuff get close enough to pick off a worker or two, suddenly, you're behind in resource generation. It also gives a good incentive to push into the enemy base without seeking a kill shot. It's a great way to motivate the conflict. 

Aside from this one large change that is, as far as I know, unique to this title, this game defines itself by the details. The sci-fi theme is well implemented and resonates with the gameplay. I like that most units have a twist to them that goes beyond weapon damage and hull strength; everything has knockback, piercing attacks, chain attacks, or special defenses or debuffs. The interplay of these abilities dominates the strategy, which is good. The numbers matter, but aren't the main reason for victory unless there is a major mismatch. A well-composed force can defeat a numerically superior enemy--and I mean unit selection, not that you have to build things in the right order and at the right time. Timing matters, of course, as there is travel time, so sending reinforcements becomes a waste beyond a certain point, but as long as you put something up front that can take a hit, usually your flotillas will arrange themselves in a reasonable way before the enemy forces can break their back. 

It's easy to understand and play, but there is interesting depth you wouldn't expect. It's worth your time if you like tugs of war, and it would make a good introduction for someone who hasn't played them before. I'd classify this game as a backlog gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198160278225', 'num_games_owned': 420, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 24176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1642533211}
review:
Игра очень понравилась, именно такими должны быть инди-проекты. 
Затягивает, и играется легко и интересно. 
Очень рекомендую.

Сюжет: Игра "Aeon Command" -  представляет из себя сайд-скроллер стратегию, где мы, управляя одной из трёх фракций, боремся за ресурсы туманности Аеон. 
Борьба эта, в большинстве случаев напоминает перетягивание каната, поскольку лидерство попеременно переходит то к одному оппоненту, то к другому.

Геймплей: Основной игровой процесс происходит без нашего участия. 
Едва покинув доки космической базы, добывающие ресурсы корабли и их военные товарищи действуют автономно: первые начинают перерабатывать астероиды, вторые - летят громить противника. 
Именно так - стоит выпустить с базы первый боевой корабль, и он тут же полетит в стан врага, потому момент постройки первого такого корабля и служит началом боевых действий.

Сама игра: Практически всё, за что мы отвечаем - это когда и какой тип корабля построит наша база.
Попутно мы можем улучшать показатели обшивки кораблей и их боевую мощь(до пяти раз каждый), а так же изредка помогать своему флоту в противостоянии с противником: накопив энергии, в зависимости от фракции, мы можем как усилить свою армию, так и ослабить вражью.
Игра разрабатывалась под iOS и Android, потому особых откровений ожидать не стоит - это касается и наполнения игры, и управления, которое заточено под тачскрин.
 
Но всё же, если вам нравится космическая тематика(а атмосфера Космических рейнджеров и S.P.A.Z. - не пустой звук), стоит обратить внимание на эту игру, благо 4-5 часов, затраченных на прохождение кампании, проходят быстро и в меру увлекательно.
 
К тому же выглядит Aeon Command вполне симпатично и звучит под стать.
Забавная игра. затягивает и играется легко и интересно. Но надолго не хватит, все бои однотипные. 
Хоть игра на Английском, но всё же очень быстро осваиваешь простую механику, основанную на правильном подборе кораблей, улучшений. 
Игра стоит недорого, со скидкой так вообще выходит отличная вещь. Конечно есть недочёты, в игре многого не хватает.

Плюсы:
+Карточки;
+Ачивки;
+Цена.

Минусы:
-Одиночная компания очень хромает, но на многое можно закрыть глаза.

Рекомендую!!!
Моя оценка 8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198076167349', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1555553167}
review:
I was about to criticize the game for basically just being a game of tug-of-war in space. But, lo and behold the game actually considers that a selling point.

The game is only 3 bucks (though I’m pretty sure I paid more for it), and honestly it’s hardly worth that. The problem is that there’s not much to the game. You rapid click miner ships until you reach capacity and then spam enemies without ever really knowing which particular ship might perform better than the others or what particular niche they fill. Half of the time I forget what any of the ships  do and just click them hoping for the best. But, after a while I decided that choosing arbitrarily between 8 kinds of ships took too much brain power and realized it hardly makes a difference if I just alternate between 2. The game calls itself a strategy game but after 11 hours I have yet to find myself in a situation where I need to use strategy. The steam page uses various buzz terms like “take control of your mother ship” and “play” when the game itself is little more than staring at two hive-mind AIs mash stupidly with each other until one of them emerges victor.

Also, I left out the part where the game is stupidly easy. That seriously is no exaggeration; I basically broke the game without any glitches or hacks—on hard mode mind you. All it really takes is spamming cheap ships while the other team is still building up. It’s enough to cripple their start enough that it takes no time at all to steamroll them. No joke, I was able to win hardmode skirmishes in 3 minutes or less 100% of the time. Once you master that (which is not hard to do) then there’s no real game left because of course multiplayer is dead.

Don’t buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171335229', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 646, 'last_played': 1526829474}
review:
On the surface, this seems like it could be a decent little game. In fact, it kind of is... except there are just too many cons to make it recommended. The good points are good rather than great; but the bad points are dreadful (some not the fault of the actual game).

PROS
+ You can choose one of three factions to play as
+ Very easy learning curve
+ Graphics are functional and don't obscure game area
+ Atmospheric music that doesn't distract or detract from the gameplay
+ Very easy achievements, although a little on the grindy side

CONS
- Muliplayer is essentially dead, which removes the only replay value in the game
- Skirmish against the AI is easy, even on 'Hard' mode
- Despite the easy learning curve, the game isn't hard to master in Skirmish
- Using Exiles faction and spamming the "Last Stand" perk allows cheap Rocketeers to destroy enemy faction
- Campaign is a joke (way too easy) - it's more like a tutorial to ease you into each new ship or perk

I can only recommend this game if:
1. you want easy achievements; and
2. you love strategy games.

For the majority of people, I do NOT recommend this game, hence my rating.
It's a shame because it's not a bad game - just too bland and also the dead multiplayer.

review:
Aeon Command - простенькая стратегия, созданная двумя людьми, которая затянет вас на пару часов. Цель каждой миссии - разгромить врага, который обосновался на другом конце карты. Наши корабли летят и убивают врагов в автоматическом режиме, и нам остается только нажимать на иконки кораблей, которые хотим заказать и собирать бонусы, которые выпадают с поверженных кораблей. 

Плюсы: 

[h1]Атмосфера: музыка и задний фон[/h1]
Выполненны вполне аутентично: первые минуты игры я любовался красивым звездным небом и слушал неспешную пространное звучание. С погружением в пучины космоса у игры все в порядке.

[h1]Кампания: разнообразие миссий[/h1]
После краткого обучения нам перед заданием уничтожить противника будут ставить "сюжетные" задания. Защитить корбаль, накопить ресурсы, улучшить корабли. Будут попадаться миссии на необычных картах, например "укороченная" или с обилием ресурсов. В кампании выжет весь сок из игры. 

[h1]Кампания: сложность[/h1]
В отличии от скримиша, сложность кампании не регулируется и зависит от условий задания. И просто понастроить мощных кораблей и выиграть не получиться - в каждом задании предстоит немного подумать и решить задачу самым оптимальным образом, чтобы добиться и ужержать преимущество. 

[h1]Карточки и предметы сообщества[/h1]
Если вы приобрели ее бесплатно, как я, или по весомой скидке, то карточки могут накинуть вам немного рублей на счет. А если вы решите крафтить значок, то вам могут достаться красивые обои или редкие обои, которые стоят около 200 рублей. Один такой предмет я продал и обогатился на короткое время. Так что крафт значка вполне оправдан. 


Минусов немногим больше, но они куда весомее. 

[h1] Кампания: продолжительность и сюжет [/h1]
Продолжительность кампании не самая большая. Я прошел ее за 1,5 часа, все остальные 11 часов ушли у меня на набивку ачивок. Сюжет простецкий: Альянс защищает подконтрольную систему Aeon от вторжения Киборгов, которые априори плохие, а также от "Странников", родная система которых была уничтожена этими самыми Киборгами и "Странники" теперь ищут новый дом. Хотя от этой игры никто и не просил эпичного сюжета и в рамках этой игры он не реализуем. 
 
[h1]Скримиш и онлайн[/h1]
Мультиплеерная игра мертва, в скримиш играть попросту скучно и он создан чисто для набива ачивок. 

[h1]Цена[/h1]
Полная цена игры не оправдывает себя. Если хотите получить одноразовое удовольствие от этой игры, то получайте ее бесплатно или по скидке от 90%.

[h1]Итог:[/h1] 
Хорошая инди-игра, но только с условием, если она достанется вам за копейки. После прохождения кампании делать в ней нечего, разве что набивать ачивки, что тоже весьма муторно. Так что ждите скидок и раздач, и забирайте этот маленький шедевр.

review:
Yllättävän viihdyttä kliksuttelupeli, joka muistuttaa köydenvetoa/dotaa pelitavaltaan.

Lähtöasetelmana on suora kaistale avaruutta, jonka molemmissa päissä on emoalus. Sitten vaan kliksutellaan aluksia alaruudun valikosta esiin. Alukset ovat tietokoneohjattuja, joten itse pelaajalle ei jää muuta virkaa kuin ostella niitä ja kehittää alusten tehoja ostamalla päivitysosia Research-valikon alta. Alukset vaihtelevet minereista erilaisiin sota-aluksiin ja parantajiin. Pelissä on kolme joukkuetta: Alliance, Cyborgs sekä Exiles ja jokaisella on toki omat aluksensa sekä erikoisvoimansa. Pelissä räiskinnän ohessa kerättävät mutteriupgradepalikat voi käyttää pelin menu-valikossa pysyviin päivitysosiin (näitä on jokaisella factionilla omat + yleiset päivitykset, jotka pätevät kaikkiin rotuihin).

Eli helppoa kuin heinänteko, mutta ihanan koukuttavaa. Harmi vain, että kyseessä on todella iisi ja lyhyt peli. Itseltäni meni kaikkien kampanjoiden läpäisemiseen kolmisen tuntia. Ikävintä kaikessa oli se, että sitten kun oli vähän hankkinut pysyviä päivityksiä ja keksinyt voittavan taktiikan, niin sillä samalla taktiikalla voitti kaikki jaksot tosta noin vaan. Taisin hävitä kolme kertaa niiden n. 30 jakson aikana mitä pelistä löytyy. Eli haastavaksi tätä ei voi millään tasolla kutsua.

Vioistaan huolimatta viihdyttävä ja koukuttava pelimuoto, josta olisi mukava nähdä kunnollinen laitos joskus tulevaisuudessa jonkun isomman firman toimesta. Pelistä löytyy myös nettipelimahdollisuus, mutta en tiedä pelaako tätä kukaan netissä. Toista ihmistä vastaan tämä voisi olla hemmetin hauskaa. Bussin odottelu -skenen kärkikahinoihin ehdottomasti kuitenkin solahtaa tämä tekele, sillä itselläni kesti 15 minuuttia pisin taistelu, joten pikaiset sessiot luonnistuvat kuin vettä vaan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131816676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1505224294}
review:
Aeon combat è un RTS molto semplificato.
Il gioco prevede due astronavi, l’una contro l’altra per il dominio spaziale. Ogni nave può, tramite piccole astronavi minerarie, raccogliere risorse per costruire la propria flotta. Ogni astronave creata marcerà autonomamente verso la nave nemica, senza che debba essere guidata in nessun modo. Esiste inoltre un’altra risorsa, l’energia, necessaria per attivare vari power-up. 
Esistono tre fazioni, e ognuna di queste ha sia navi che poteri  diversi tra loro. Avremo il caccia classico, la nave che genera scudi, le navi d’assalto pesante ecc…
Il gioco in se non è male, ed è anche divertente. Ma ha due difetti che non possono essere trascurati:

1)	La campagna è breve e facile, e serve soltanto ad introdurre tutte le navi presenti nel gioco. In più è presente una modalità online, dove però come mi aspettavo non ho trovato nessuno.

2)	Lo stile grafico minimalista non mi ha coinvolto per niente, Ho trovato la grafica semplice e pulita, ma anche noiosa e poco accattivante. Sono comunque ben fatte le esplosioni e gli effetti particellari.

Aeon command è un piccolo RTS rilassante, che potrebbe valere la pena provare, magari con un amico. Non presenta una vera e propria sfida, ma comunque è divertente e molto bilanciato grazie soprattutto alla grande varietà di navi presente nel gioco.

7/10

TLDR: Flash game grade tower defense clicker hybrid that can keep you moderately busy for a few hours. Experience is entirely forgettable. Multiplayer is dead, and the game is not very impressive on any level. Action is indirect as all you control are ship purchases and spending on upgrades and cooldowns, the rest is AI controlled. Removed for declutter 

Similar to Age of Steel:Recharge. This is a simple battle royale/tug of war game in which you spam ships and use rock paper scissor mechanics and cooldown powers to try to defeat your enemies base. The permanent upgrades can keep you busy past the short campaign but it simply makes the aleady simple single player experience boil down to a mix of grinding and perserverance. Alternatively you can just focus on lower cost spammable ship upgrades. The occasional insta death vortexes in some maps can force the use of different ships but they are an easily overcome obstacle that does not bring much to the table. I usually experience better handled and more entertaining space battles as a subcomponent of a greater game, usually in 4X games but even real time strategy and some tower defense games would surpass this in terms of mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138213224', 'num_games_owned': 1195, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1464301850}
review:
[h1]Experiência:[/h1]

Aeon Command é um jogo extremamente simples, porém que exige sabedoria, tenho quase 2 horas dentro dele e finalizei grande parte da campanha, aliás, pretendo finalizar tudo até o fim do mês. Pessoalmente adoro jogos de naves e ainda mais com visuais simples, como é o caso, mas este jogo foi uma grata surpresa, sendo o primeiro que experimentei que tem essa temática um pouco diferente do convencional.

[h1]O fundamental para você saber: [/h1]

Bom, você deve ter plena ciência de que você não vai controlar tudo que pensa... As naves tem sua própria IA- inteligência artificial - por isso é preciso ter muita noção de quando e o que criar - espaçonaves - o jogo é basicamente clicar e observar o que acontece em seguida, olhando a raça adversária enquanto se preocupa em atacar, defender e ainda coletar recursos para fabricar seus equipamentos e consequentemente evoluir sua frota.

Um grande ponto fraco do jogo é a falta de uma história complexa, já que estamos falando de espaçonaves, sobrevivência, estratégia... Infelizmente o jogo peca nisso, colocando algumas raças como escolha e te largando para fazer aquilo que narrei no primeiro parágrafo. O jogo é tão simples neste quesito, que fica até difícil passar mais informações do que isso para auxiliar vocês na compra, porém o tópico abaixo pode ajudar - ou não - você a decidir.

[h1]O gameplay:[/h1]

Basicamente eu já expliquei ele, mas vamos rever os pontos para você ter certeza se é o que você espera. O game é "clicar e observar" que em outras palavras é apenar clicar e ver o que acontece em seguida, sempre fazendo aquilo que você pensa ser prioridade, cada nave tem seu tempo de construção, armas e utilidade, então você vai ter que pensar bem se ela vale os recursos - e o tempo - necessário para construir, também vai ter que usar o bom senso em ver se precisa de mais recursos e atacar depois ou chegar já tocando suas naves para cima da nave-mãe inimiga.

O jogo é bem simples e você não vai ter nenhuma dificuldade de aprender, isso não quer dizer que o jogo seja fácil... Bem pelo contrário, existes missões e missões, cada uma vai exigir um pouco mais de você do que a anterior e as mesmas estratégias não costumam funcionam já que os inimigos não fazem sempre a mesma coisa, então muito cuidado para não confundir um jogo simples com um jogo fácil, pois não é o caso.

[b]Prós:[/b]

- Gráficos simples, porém belos.
- Apesar do sistema de cliques, o jogo é emocionante.
- Exige estratégia e velocidade de raciocínio.
- Custo beneficio.
- Multiplataforma.
- Multiplayer online.
- Roda em basicamente qualquer PC/Dispositivo.

[b]Contra:[/b]

- Falta de uma história digna.
- O desenvolvedor deveria investir mais no jogo.
- A falta de novos conteúdo, isso faz você "Encostar" o jogo após zerar.

[h1]Nota: 8/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198013429772', 'num_games_owned': 2524, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1475657487}
review:
This is a really fun game 'IF' your a fan of space combat games, basically it is tug of war in space with fleets that are automated and outside of your control blowing each other up. In this game you only select what to build/deploy which makes the game a more cinematic experience then a traditional interaction heavy video game, however with all being said and done once you have completed the single player campaign the game kind of loses its appeal since multiplayer is a graveyard and skirmish against the computer is repetitive and boring, skirmish only becomes interesting if you are playing at the more challenging difficulties.

I give this game a thumbs up but be warned multiplayer is effectively dead and skirmish against the computer (once you have finished the single player campaign) requires you to play at the hard or insane difficulty level for it to be interesting.

I recommend Aeon Command for people who like both space and casual video games as well as for those people looking for a video game that is more of a cinematic experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083736752', 'num_games_owned': 526, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1472349626}
review:
Aeon Command developed by Bat Country Games & released on 3rd July 2014 for the PC version. It has an average user score of 6.8 on Metacritic  (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/aeon-command) & is categorized under the "Strategy" genre. 

You'd be surprised to find out that Bat Country Game is an independent game company comprising of only  2 developer. Does Aeon Command live up to it's promises? Marketed as a strategy space game, collect resources and fight among 3 faction to take control of Aeon Nebula. As a RTS *PC* gamer, I will cry foul over the game's description but coming from a mobile device gamer, I certainly welcome Aeon Command. Does that sound confusing? Read on to be enlightened!

The controls are very simple. You can play the entire game by just using Mouse clicks. You also have keyboard shortcut keys to execute production of units/skills on the fly.

The visuals are just fine for me. This is a 2D space battle game. The space background & the ambient sound sets the tone for being in space. Each faction will have different designs of ships. Each ship will have different animations and audio for their weapons. The User Interface is kept simple and clean. Nothing fancy/cluttered. 

The Story
As the game is marketed, there is  3 faction to choose from in the campaign mode, each having 8 levels - so making it a total of 24 levels. At the beginning of each level, you will be given a balloon message that describes the story@scenario to you - and what follows after that is..well a tug of war of endless wave of space crafts.

You practically try to overwhelm your enemy by mass producing space crafts and the ships will fly to the other end of the map trying to blow up the other faction's mother ship by themselves. You have no ability to control them. You only can decide the sequence of space craft to build. That's it. It is a 1 Lane tug of war and the best part is that you will be doing the same exact thing for 24 times regardless of the "story". 

Sure, there are a few levels with twist in the story, take for an example where you have to survive for x minute against the cyborg faction who are sending endless suicidal crafts. After X minute, you'll have to eliminate them.  It's just sending 1,000,000 space craft to the other side of the map. for 24 times! Do not be mistaken, this is not a MOBA or Tower defense. The exact description would be a 1 Lane control. That's it.

You must be wondering how is this even possible for a game with such dull, uninteresting, repetitive game play is receiving "very positive" feedbacks on steam? For a RTS fan, you certainly would be utterly disappointed. There is very little "Strategy" involved. It's designed to be as a macro level management kind of game. One that is more suited/geared towards casual gamers. Its "fun" when you can overwhelm your opponent with 1 gazillion space craft. especially on multiplayer.

Aeon Command gives players the option to upgrade your space crafts and also your factions(think of it like a faction bonus). The spacecraft may look and feel different however they will always remain in the same "type of class" for every faction. 

Your first space craft will always be a close range combat craft followed by a long range craft and then a support craft (healing/shield/disabler etc). It may feel slightly different from each faction but that's the general concept. It's not like starcraft/warcraft/red alert/supreme commander where you really have different kind of units! Even plant vs Zombie has more "strategy". I am sorry but that's how I feel/see this product as.

On multiplayer, you have  3 game mode:
[list]
    [*]Classic: Your typical normal game.
    [*]Close: Your typical normal game but with an inch closer to each other.
    [*]Resource: Your typical normal game with no-cap limit on your harvester unit.
[/list]

I don't understand the minor differences in Close and Resources mode. Is this the best the design could come up with? The game engine limitation? If this was a tug of war, the close mode is like having a shorter rope by an inch and for the resource mode, you can have endless of people to pulling the rope. It may sound like a visible idea but in reality, the result doesn't mean anything! There is no difference in strategy/approach of playing. I always perform the same step - across all faction - on all level difficulty.

My Summary
Aeon Command is a straightforward game - which can be fun - however for any serious RTS fan, stay clear of this title, it is not what it's marketed to be. For me, the story is non-existent. There is little strategy. No, I dont take upgrades as strategy. The game play was uninteresting. Some flash games could even provide me with better gaming experience/fun. Overall, I had a dull gaming experience. Do I want to see another game made with this concept/game design? No! On the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for Aeon Command is a 4/10. 

I am sorry Bat Country Game, you'd have to do better than this. The product feels like a flash game with uninteresting value. No replay value. No challenge. If there was an option for players to secure some sort of critical resource point, or upgrading the ship with different abilities (not just increase the damage or hp), the ability to move your mother ship for base expansion - something that can get player to engage with the game - so that players can feel some sort of strategy is involved, introduce new game mode in campaign apart from obliterating your opponent; escort mission, reconnaissance, explore other planets/moons/etc maybe? Anything but a dull straightforward obliterating your opponent 24 times. TWENTY FOUR TIMES! T.T

I didn't even get a chance to interact with a faction; no interaction at all apart from blowing them to bits. Story telling department leaves much to be desired. I am speechless at this point. I don't dislike this product, in fact I want to see a better version. I hope you can think this through for your future games because you are an  independent game company, you are not bound/tied to other company restrictions. You have the freedom to develop something in your vision. Good luck in DYE & I hope to see something interesting/fresh from you.

review:

Both are Tug's and work generally the same.
But Desert Strom is FREE and this game costs money. The only upside is, this game can be played solo and Dester storm is Multiplayer only with a steep learning curve.

You spawn units at your base that run to the enemy. in Aeon Command you have to built all units by hand and can only use your special "magics" to influence the battle.

In Desert Storm you place your units, which involves a lot of strategy, upgrade units, where you know what you upgrade and its a lot better then Aeon Command.

When you like Tug play Desert Storm for free, the only way you wanna play this is for easy 100% Achievements or when you dont wanna play against other human beings.

review:

Often representing three dimensional space in two dimensions is a tricky task but 'Aeon Command' solves this problem by reducing it down to just one dimension.

The basic formula is sound but without the ability to control or even group units it leaves the player with barely anything to do but press the 'make ship' button until the momentum swings to their side.  There are multiple upgrade paths that will add some variance but little can be done to improve the game's snail pace and lack of interaction.

review: If your looking at this game and thinking back to tug of war type games in wc3 or sc2 don't. This is unfortunately not that kind of game but it's not bad either. It's a lot more simple, no auto building units or no income link to unit's produced. You send out miners and then manually pump out units as you unlock new ones and upgrade the ones you have. Battles tend to snowball out of control fast so you won't see too much back and forth. There are persistent upgrades which unfortunately makes it a bit grindy as you will probably be bored by the easy computer long before you have enough of these upgrades to make fighting the normal computer a fair fight. So in closing it's fun but don't buy this expecting any real depth or to be playing it for months.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985795611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 302, 'last_played': 1464746648}
review:
Very fun little game. Took me around 4-5 hours to go through the campaigns but it was very pleasant. Plan to definitely play more now and then.

This game does the "hands-off" -approach well - instead of microing you need to think about the fleet composition and when exactly to launch your ships and how many/what kind. For example, ships in a cluster kill targets fast and don't really take much damage in return..but certain ships have AOE-abilities that really hurt clusters. There is also the question of whether to research upgrades or to send out un-upgraded ships faster. The activated abilities require good timing to get the maximum value out of. 

I felt like the difficulty only really picked up some in the last campaign, so I think the campaigns could have been harder and/or have couple more "hard" missions near the end. But that is a minor complaint.

So overall:
+ gameplay
+ graphics and sound
+ concept - it works
+ upgrade/research system

author: {'steamid': '76561198113159709', 'num_games_owned': 2274, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1387, 'last_played': 1461947289}
review:
已通过+全成就
进包很多次，休闲游戏，很不错的，值得一玩。
虽然没有中文，但是英文不难，摸索一下就会了。
太空背景的拉锯战(tug-of-war)[spoiler] 应该是叫这个名字吧，就是前几年手机上很火的那种类型，双方在地图两头出兵，把对方基地摧毁[/spoiler]。这个游戏太空场景很不错，一些细节也很棒，比如飞船加速和减速的时候能明显感受到加速度，还有飞船掉头也需要时间等等。
一共三个阵营，每个阵营都有7架飞机，分别对应快捷键1-7，其中1号飞机是采集资源的，2-7是战斗的。每个阵营还有3个技能，对应快捷键QWE，R键是打开升级菜单。
战役模式一共3章，分别对应3个阵营，用来熟悉每个阵营的单位和技能。
优点：
+每个阵营的单位和技能都是不同的，用不同的阵营有不同的游戏体验；
+对战模式下有个混乱阵营，是随机3个阵营下的单位和技能，很有趣。可以尝试不同单位之间以及技能的组合；
+平衡性不错；
+多样的升级系统；
+画面也挺好的；
+可以联网对战。
缺点：
-暂停太不方便，没有直接的按钮，也没有快捷键(至少我没找到)，每次暂停都得先打开菜单，然后再点暂停；
-战役过短，最后只能对战模式刷刷刷了；
-一些辅助作用的单位有时候会出现bug，但是不影响玩；
-无法连接到服务器，不知道是我这里网的问题还什么
成就部分：
全成就比较简单
完成战役模式就会解锁3个成就；
菜单里的升级全部完成会解锁2个成就；
Overhealing：一次战斗中回复5000伤害，Alliance阵营的第一个技能就是回血，多用几次；
Boom? Boom!：一次战斗中使用Alliance阵营的第三个技能nukes 10次；
Mmm Eggs：在对战模式用混乱阵营(SCRAMBLE)打赢混乱阵营
Greedy：一次战斗存1000个资源，就是钻石那个。
Destroyer：这个是最费劲的，累计摧毁5000个敌军单位。我后期一直在刷这个，速推的话一局才摧毁不到100个。
[spoiler]速推方法：一开始造1号飞机，攒资源，等敌机快到家门口的时候开始不停的造2号战机(Exile阵营要造3号战机)[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198140179267', 'num_games_owned': 319, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1460585327}
review:
Jednoduchá strategie ve vesmíru. Dvě mateřské lodi, flotila sběračů surovin a arzenál bitevních člunů, které na sebe soupeři navzájem vysílají. Cílem je udržet frontovou linii, soupeře přetlačit a zničit jeho mateřskou loď.
Grafika je jednoduchá, ale hezky udělaná, ovládání bezproblémové. Oceňuji hudbu, která je správně kosmicky ambientní a nevtíravá (pamětníkům možná připomene Imperium Galactica 2).
Lze hrát v režimu kampaně (která zároveň funguje jako nenásilný tutorial), cvičného souboje nebo hráče proti hráči (tam jsem ale nikdy nenašel nikoho, kdo by čekal ve frontě). Je tu i sekce vylepšení, kde si během kampaně můžete vylepšovat jednotky své armády.

Všechno to zní moc dobře, ale celý koncept je příliš prostý. Chybí tomu hloubka nebo prvek náhody, který by zajistil znovuhratelnost. Jak jednou projdete celou hru, vylepšíte všechny jednotky a osvojíte si ideální strategii, nemáte důvod si Aeon Command dál držet na disku. Je to prostě oddechovka po práci, která vám vydrží s trochou štěstí na dva týdny. Vhodná pro sběratele her, karet a achievementů (vcelku bezproblémových 100 %).

author: {'steamid': '76561197996890045', 'num_games_owned': 3060, 'num_reviews': 293, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1456034143}
review:
Aeon Command is a linear game, where your mother ship is at the left end of a space area and the enemy mother ship is at the right end.

You mine resources and then use the resources to build ships (there are extra ships to unlock, research to be done, and upgrades to be had).
The unlocks are on the main menu; not in game, as I had expected, so it took a while to find them (doh).

As soon as you build your warships, they head off to attack the enemy.
You can't issue commands to your ships, such as getting them to attack a particular enemy, hold position, retreat, or whatever - so that sucks; it limited the tactical abilities of the game severely.

As an aside, I'm not sure if one achievement is broken or not, "Destroyer: Destroy 5,000 ships."
Despite destroying many ships, I have 0/5,000 for this achievement.
Maybe it's only for multiplayer games (if it is, it certainly doesn't say so), but when I tried to have a multiplayer game, there were no other players available - so, maybe that says a lot for the game in itself.

This is a very limited game. It might be ok for 5 to 12 year olds, who don't have high expectations.
Apart from that, I wouldn't bother with it - unless you have some time to waste and nothing better to do.

review:
4.7 Hours on record - here's what I think.
All in all, I enjoy the game.  It's not a particularly complex, or in-depth strategy game, but to those who enjoyed the flash game Age of War, it will be entertaining.  The interface allows keyboard commands, which increases playability significantly.  There are campaigns to go through, but my favorite part is playing scramble in scenario mode, where each unit is randomly selected front one of the playable races.  It's generally a resource management game, where you try to mine as much as possible and upgrade your units as fast as possible while keeping the enemy at bay so you can eventually overwhelm them.  It is surprisingly replayable, because there are times that I have had matches lasting 3 minutes, and sometimes they last 10.  I would recommend this game as an intermitten time waster, because if you sit down and drill through, you will beat this game very quickly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998647125', 'num_games_owned': 840, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1561866403}
review:
A tug of war that would be heinous if priced higher, but at 3$ without discounts, it's a good buy.

Pros:
Provides quite a bit of gameplay for its price tag.

Cons:
Enemy AI is overpowered in skirmish. Simply put, they get resource ramps, multiplied by difficulty, that results in an un-fun, artificial (not influenced by your gameplay or strategy whatsoever) challenge on anything higher than easy.
Matchmaking is non-existent due to lack of players.
Abilities, the sole direct influence you have on the battlefield, are unnecessary if you know which ships to build and upgrade. The AI abuses them with nearly unlimited amounts of energy on anything above easy.
Completionist achievement expects entirely unrealistic amount of time devoted to harvesting skirmish wins for upgrades.

Why do I recommend it with such glaring flaws? My played time and $3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044953582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 413, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1457615351}
review:
A surprisingly simple but very okay game.

I'd vote against getting this if you expect some super dramatic and graphical spaceship war game, but if you know what you're looking for - a basic Build-and-Watch tactical game - then this would be a very good bet. I'd not call it 'bare bones' so much as admit it's a very simple game that focuses more on the planning and gameplay than anything else; that's not to say that they ignored everything else, but you can easily see what their best aspect is.

Difficulty-wise, I'd say it's too easy. I like a challenge now and again, and the thing here is that with a simple game comes a simple A.I. - one that needs a bit of a boost (resource-wise) to keep up with an actual planning player (and will nearly always still fall short to one who's actually on their feet and assiging commands properly). That's not to say the game's not fun - there's still a simple satisfaction in playing it and seeing your amassed army do the dirty work for you.

Achievements-wise, this game will take you a while. It's rather easy to hit 100% since the story mode is a glorified tutorial and introduction (with smatterings of plot, I guess) and the career achievements are really ones that would take you a fair bit of time. It wont even take you that long to come up with a winning build that could consistently win you games at 4-5minutes each and it's just a matter, then, of putting in the hours.

Overall, I would recommend it. It's simple but good, and the for the price, matches expectations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198179372866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1450162311}
review:
DISCLAIMER: This recommendation is based on playing the game in short and casual spurts and buying it on sale.

Aeon Command is a simple RTS with a few mechanics here and there that make it great to pick up when you need to waste 5-10 minutes really quickly. And for that, it does it well.

PROS: 

-Campaign that walks you through all the mechanics of the game in an easy to understand way
-Nice and simple art that gets the job done. 
-Performance is good. Runs smoothly on my 2012 laptop.
-Has three different modes and three different factions. Also gives you the option of scrambling all the units and factions together in skirmish mode (1 on 1 against the AI)
-Steam achievements that force you to play in a few ways you would not normally do. 


CONS:
-Lacks variety of gameplay. The three types of skirmish modes are not that different from each other
-Inability to control ships. You are mainly making strategic decisions on what and when to build. You also have some tactical decisions to make when using small perks/abilities like healing, nuking, etc.
-Limited tactical/strategic depth. The most you'll get out of this is scrambling your units in skirmish mode and figuring out the best strategy to use the mix of units
-Less tug of war and more "quick momentum"  type game. You can rarely recover from a bad decision and once the AI takes advantage it's basically over. 
-Multiplayer is nonexistent


Overall it's a good casual time waster. It looks nice and I like to play it for 15 minutes or so when I'm listening to podcasts or music. Judging from a casual game perspective it's a good buy. Otherwise, just get it in a bundle or on a good sale.

review:
Чего-то я в этой жизни не понимаю...
Смотрю на рейтинг - очень положительно...
Смотрю на комменты - дофига позитива...
Смотрю на цену - 79 р, на скидке 18р...
Смотрю на скрины - простенько, но симпотишно...
Смотрю на наличие карточек - имеются...
Однообразный и повторяющийся текст, не находите?
И он в точности отображает игру.
Был когда-то популярен жанр флешевых малюхоньких игрулек аля стенка на стенку, суть которых была в том что бы расчекрыжить замок\базу противника, находящийся на другой стороне экрана.
Игрок не контролирует сам юнит, а назначает очередь постройки и улучшений. Появившись юнит сразу прет на базу противника, попутно постреливая во все вражеское пока не помрет.
Концепт у такого жанра прост, но затягивает.
В данной игре имеется сюжет подающийся текстом.
Три разные фракции бадаются друг с другом, выясняя у кого "корабли" больше.
Помимо сюжетки есть скирмиш и мультиплеер...
Чего то я в этой жизни не понимаю...
КАК? Ну как такой шлак просачивается в гринлайт? Кто эти люди, что голосуют за это?
ДЕВЯТЬ! Девять карт, каждая максимум на 4 минуты... даже не на 5!
AI даже на харде настолько не алё, что выносится за ТРИ минуты.
ОДНА мелодия на все карты и фракции!
И если в преснопамятных флешках приходилось подумать, что грейдить и какие типы войск строить и в каком порядке, то тут и сюжет и мультик выигрывается тупым спамом одного типа самолетика.
Отдельно доставляют ачивки... Уничтожить 5000 вражин - при том что самое большее удавалось натыкать 30-40 за миссию. Или проапгрейдить ВСЕ тех.ветки (да да тут есть апгрейды влияющие равно ни на что), которых по 10 на каждую фракцию и еще десятка общих улучшений. Для полного апа одной ветки нужно 10 поинтов, которые получаем за победу в количестве 5 шт. То биж, надо сыграть МИНИМУМ сотню игр....
Иной мотивации провести в игре более 20 минут разраб не осилил.
И вишенкой на торте: в сообществе есть ПОДРОБНЫЙ гайд по ачивкам... 
По всем трем....
Чего-то я в этой жизни не понимаю...
 
Если брать на скидке выше 75, то карточки игру окупают. Но поверьте - оно того не стоит. Потому что многократное повторение одного и того же действия с ожиданием разных результатов это безумие.

review:
Fun Game, very good for when you have a short time to play something.  After going through the tutorial challenges  (which are fun and challenging) to get to know the various ship and weapon types of the three races, I started in on skirmish mode, where I can pick the Range (Close or Regular), the Resource Availability (10 asteroids or 25), the Difficulty of the AI opponent (Easy, Medium, or Hard), and I can set my Side to be ...Regular, Random, or Scrambled. Scrambled sends you out with a fleet comprised of vessels from all three of the races, so you never know what you will have for your battle fleet.

My games last from about 4 minutes...  to the longest game ran 21 minutes for me.  So its a nice "I got 15 -20 minutes to Kill '  game.   I also very much enjoyed that hint of a BSG feel to the ship construction in some of the fleets.

All in all, its a game I enjoy and will go back to again and again for a quick mental refresh and an entertainment 'pick me up'.   I definitely recommend it.

review:
Aeon Command é mais uma daquelas gratas surpresas que volta e meia encontramos na Steam por um preço absurdamente barato. Eu Estava navegando pelo site da Steam e fui ver as promoções e após passar várias páginas acabei achando este jogo por R$ 1,57, de começo não me chamou atenção, mas pelo preço? valeu arriscar.

Comecei a jogar o game e não vi o tempo passar, é realmente viciante e muito bem feito. 
Aeon Command é um jogo de estratégia onde vamos ter de administrar naves e poderes e assim destruir os inimigos usando muita estratégia e evoluindo suas unidades.

Pontos Positivos:

+ Campanha (8 Missões em cada facção com diferentes tipos de naves e poderes)
+ Gráficos (Simples, mas bem executado) 
+ Suporte a Cross-platform Multiplayer
+ Sistema de Upgrade
+ Super facil de aprender a jogar, mas com uma boa dificuldade.

Pontos Negativos:

- O trabalho de som poderia ser melhor e ter uma trilha sonora mais variada entre as missões, o jogo perde um pouco da emoção por este motivo.
- Multiplayer apesar de bem feito é praticamente sem jogadores.
- Praticamente sem enredo, o quê pode afastar alguns jogadores.

Aeon Command não é um jogo perfeito e poderia ter uma campanha mais longa e uma trilha sonora mais variada, a ausência de um enredo mais complexo pode afastar jogadores mais exigentes. Porém, se você levar em conta o preço do jogo ele vale totalmente a pena. É um jogo divertido, bem simples de se jogar e com uma ótima dificuldade.

Seja em uma promoção como a que eu peguei ou seu preço full de R$ 6,29 eu recomendo totalmente Aeon Command!

Aeon Command - Game Review - 8/10

     This post is going to be pretty short compared to the usual. Nice and short, just like Aeon Command.

     If you've ever played one of those flash games where you make units and they move across the map and attack your enemy, then you've played Aeon Command. I wouldn't call this a bad game. It's definitely not my favourite, nor does it have the strategic complexity that I prefer, but for only $3.29 on Steam, it did provide me more than 3 hours of entertainment. Granted, once I figured out how to beat the game... most of the rest of the time was spent farming wins until I could get the last research only because I wanted the last achievement.

     This game is simple, and that's not a bad thing. It's meant to be a simple "tug 'o war"-type game and it's done really well. If you're looking for something more hardcore and intense, then this game won't be for you. However, if you're looking for a cheap casual way to spend a little bit of time, then I would give this game a recommendation, especially if you can get it on sale.

     I'll give this game 8/10 for this type of game.

~ Kyle

review:
Este é um jogo de estratégia onde você só tem que saber onde e quando clicar, e isso é muito viciante, por algum motivo. Cada uma das três raças de naves e poderes diferentes e cabe a você perceber o ponto forte e fraco de cada uma delas e saber quando construir cada nave, quando fazer os upgrades e usar os poderes. A estória do jogo é fraca, só um pequeno texto antes de cada level para servir de desculpa para um novo recurso disponível para o jogador. Peguei o jogo em um bundle, joguei por algum tempo (terminei as três campanhas) e acho que o jogo vale a pena, se você gosta do estilo e não se incomodo com jogabilidade simplista. 
---------------------------------
This is a strategy game where you just have to know where and when to click, and this is very addictive for some reason. Each of the three races has different ships and power and it is up to you realize the strong and weak point of each of them and know when to build each ship, when doing upgrades and use the powers. The game's story is weak, only a small text before each level to be an excuse for a new resource available to the player. I picked up the game in a bundle, played for some time (I finished the three campaigns) and I think the game is worth it, if you like the style and do not bother with simplistic gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079519506', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1436899258}
review:
This game is simple and fun. 

You just build ships with resources that you collect to defeat the enemy. 
Though it's much more complex than that. If you don't make the correct ships at the right time, then it can cost you a lot of wasted resources, and an injection of resources or energy from your destroyed ships.

It still needs work, though. For one, the tutorial is just an extremely basic overview of everything, and the actual tutorial is in the campaign. So I would recommend to make the CURRENT "campaigns" into the tutorials, and make the campaigns more difficult as you progress, with maybe even some changes in rules sometimes to give some missions a bit more of a challenge. It would also be great for tooltips to exist, or at least a "library" of sorts with each ship's information. Perhaps give the game some more visual flair to make it look better.

All in all, it's still a pretty good game. I would recommend it to anyone who wants a rather cheap game with a rather simple concept and some little bits of fun. I just wish more people were playing multiplayer...

review:
This is "strategy lite" and kind of feels like a mobile game. Nothing wrong with that, though.

Anyways, gameplay is pretty simple. You on one side, enemy on the other. Build resource gathering ships, spam fighters of various types, upgrade some ships, and occasionally use a race specific special move. Hopefully your ship spamming was more successful than the other side and you manage to push back their fleet, and take out their mothership.

There are three races, each with their own ship types and special abilities. Each race also has their own mission mode. These missions throw some minor variable at you of various difficulty, but it usually comes down to spamming the right ships as well as spending upgrade points earned in previous missions or freeplay.

Is this game hard? Not really. Is there a lot of strategy involved? Not really. Is it kind of enjoyable? Yeah.

BTW, widescreen appears to be broken in the settings.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050486273', 'num_games_owned': 80, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1434832110}
review:
This game maybe isn't for me.
_____________________
I was reading other comments which said good things about this game. Art style, soothing music and design were all mentioned. Some mentioned tidbits about rewarding gameplay, from my experience this is completly wrong.

Once again I was to say that maybe it's not the game I was looking for.

Cons
-------------------------------
This is a space stragegy game about 3 races or factions that fight against each other. When you open up the game for the first time though, 2 of the races are locked. It seems that you have to finish each campaign before the next is unlocked. While this is all fine and dandy, it's not something I like becaise I can't just go in and play as well as something later.

The tutorial is dreadful. The game has a skirmish mode and a tutorial mode. Why do I bring up both? Because they are the same thing apart from that the tutotorial has white text overlaying the screen. The tutorial isn't a smaller easier bite-sized part of the game. It's just throwing you in and then giving you commands that come to late for you to comprehend before the AI kills you in its standard skirmish mode. There are comments where people have only beaten the tutorial after ~30 hours. While this may be hypebole, I find this to be horrible. A tutorial should teach you how to play, not be a standard difficulty challenge with overlay.

Campaign
_________________
I was never able to beat the second level of the first campaign. The reason being that no matter how fast or slow I macro, by the time a single one of my ships reaches their mothership a group of 5 ships magically appear from the enemy. Now this wouldn't be to bad as a swarming enemy is quite normal. What is horrible is that in combat a single enemy basic fighter can easily take down two of mine. It's not even a fair fight from the power standpoint let alone that they have 3 fighters and 2 bombers.

Game Design)
_________________
Nothing about this game apart from having 3 campaigns tells me this is more than a simple flash game. Its a simple click to create units and earn money game. Simple create more units and send them along a path. If I could micro the units then it would make more sense, but you don't. They ride on rails and follow and AI.



NOT WORTH TIME OR MONEY.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987068837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 756, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 541, 'last_played': 1448184269}
review:
This is a very mild recommendation - get this game if it's on sale, but don't bother at full price.  The game is interesting and engaging, but once you've completed the campaign there's really not much of anything to do.  Getting to 100% is a mind-numbing grind and replayability just isn't that fun.

Pros:
- Campaign is fun
- Each faction is unique and fun to play

Cons:
- There's a huge bug where your upgrades like auto-mining and auto-energy generation don't work at all.  I'm not sure, but this could also mean that all other Gear-related upgrades don't work either - the mining and energy related ones are the only ones that give a visual indicator of whether they're working or not. 
- Due to the above, your only chance of beating the "Hard" AI in skirmish mode is to rush them.  Then one of two things happens: You win(yay!), or more likely the enemy starts spamming energy skills which makes it impossible to beat them.  "Hard" AI seems to have an unlimited amount of energy or generates energy extremely quickly - you cannot compete if it starts using energy skills.
- You need 360 Gears to max out all upgrades.  You can earn maybe 4-7 in a "Medium" AI skirmish, and 5-7.  So you're looking at probably 70-90 rounds.  After doing the campaign and some skirmishes, I'm sitting at 34 wins, 0 losses, and nowhere close to finishing all the upgrades.
- Replayability just isn't fun.  You spam the same build orders, upgrade chain, etc.  Once you find a good starting order of things, it's just the same thing over and over and over and over and over.  With the goal of 360 gears in mind....it's just too much.

review:
You might think that a side-scrolling space game would be short about two dimensions of being  a game worth playing by current standards. You would be quite wrong. 

This is a fun and challenging game, with many decisions that must be made quickly and on the fly as each encounter develops. Build a reinforcement now, or "save up" for a small fleet of reinforcements? Build a quick fighter, or wait for the resources to build a stronger ship or a support vessel? Victory or defeat depend on the choices you make. In many ways, the strategies of this game remind me of tower defence games. BUT ... you have here a strong recommendation from a gamer who finds tower defence games—and most side-scrollers—to be tedious.

review:
First off, the tutorial is a joke!  It made me laugh pretty hard!  lol That alone was worth the .74 cents I bought this game for! lol  

Anyway, during the tutorial a real game is running in the background.  You read some text and then try some things in the real game.  You do this for a bit.  Problem is, the enemy is building up forces while you're reading and learning!  The enemy killed me way before the tutorial was over, so I couldn't do anything but quit! The text I was reading and the game over screen were mixed together making it unreadable!  LMAO!!!  Great tutorial dev's! lol

I played a skirmish after the good laugh that I had, but it was a constant tug-of-war game.  I had to quit the skirmish too as either side was not going to win and it got really boring and repetitive.  I did not play the campaign yet.  

There really isn't much to do other than click on buttons to build ships, upgrade your ships and mine for resources to build more ships, which is also automatic.  Your ships move towards the enemy mothership and try to destroy it automatically and the enemy is doing the same.  That is where the problem lies with this game.  Since you cannot control your ships, you can't stock them up.  Plus there is a pause between building ships, so your ships are sent out one at a time and usually get killed.  It's a bad design choice IMO.

Graphics and sound are okay.  Sometimes the battles are fun to watch.  You do get a few defensive weapons that you control.   You just seem to never build up enough ships fast enough to win and neither does the enemy.  I recommend this game to space combat junkies!  At the moment anyway…  I'll update this later when I spend more time with it.  I just wanted to post this real quick.

It play's really smooth on my 6 y/o Mac laptop!  Here are my system specs:  15" PowerBook Pro, Intel Core 2 Duo 2.66 GHz, 4 MB system RAM, NVIDIA GeForce 9600M GT with 256MB dedicated video RAM, running OS X version 10.6.8 (10K549), HSF+ Extended file system.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976312757', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1431429642}
review:
This is a game modeled after the mods for the RTS sub genre typically found for mods of Blizzard games called "Tug of war".

I wanted a game like this that I didn't need to run Starcraft 2 or Warcraft 3 in order to play, but I have to say that I'm quite disappointed. If you don't know what a tug of war game is, let me explain: A tug a war game is where you typically have 2 teams. Both teams have to build a structure which represents a unit which will continually spawn after set times in waves, those units will (usually) all spawn at the same time and without any control from the player, will run towards the enemy base, attacking your enemy's army as it encounters them. As time progresses and you farm more and more resources, your army gets bigger and so does your enemy's. Certain units counter certain other units so it's really up to the teams to figure out how to counter their enemy and destroy their base first. It's a huge amount of fun and very addictive.

Unfortunately, this game just has no heart at all. It's a 1v1 tug of war which will basically wear out your left mouse button as all you do is click repeatedly to create a unit. It's created instantly and there are no waves. There is, however, a spawn cooldown. It's short but it's there, which means rather than armies pushing each other in waves, you get long strings of individual ships which may or may not gather up if they stop to fight. Ships will not automatically spawn either; you click on their build icon and they spawn there once and that's it.

Incredibly boring and nothing compared to the custom mods you get in those games. I would say that if you have never played a game like this before, this might be a nice cheap (if you get it on sale) place to start. If you have Warcraft/Starcraft and want something similar to Desert Strike or Black and white, don't bother; this can't compare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041603555', 'num_games_owned': 1621, 'num_reviews': 454, 'playtime_forever': 312, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1435047396}
review:
Aeon Command can be thought of as a remake of the old strategy game "Rescue Raiders", albeit, in a sci-fi context. As a result, the commands are vastly simplified, and combat is fast. The problem is the AI relies on timing. If you build your ships in the wrong order, you're likely to lose and have no way to recover other than to die and start over, at least against AI. On the other hand, the multiplayer capability makes games a bit more unpredictable. All in all, you should at least give this game a try. 

The combat in Aeon Command is simple: you do NOT give orders to your ships. They know to engage the enemy. Instead, your job as commander is the build the units and/or deploy special abilities such as EMP, repair, and so on. There are variety of units, from simple fighters to long-range bombers to shield-bearers, and a few other units. 

You don't group ships yourself. Instead, by building them together (close in time) they will congregate and fight as a group themselves. However, this means you have to let resources accumulate to the level when you can build them in quick succession rather than building them one at a time but somehow hold them back until your signal. 

You do need to gather some resources, which are some asteroids near your mothership. You simply build a few miners (usually, one per asteroid, with one or two spares to account for travel time) and they'll do their jobs. The problem is, when enemies get too close, they will shoot at your mothership and the miners, and if you lose the mothership it's game over. And there's no way to repair the mothership should it suffer damage (but repair works on the small crafts). 

The overall objective is to conquer the map by destroying the other side's mothership, of course. 

The main problem with this game is while it plays fast, after a certain point the game's already won or lost, and there's little point to force it to continue. In other words, if you already look like you're losing, then you indeed are and there's no way you can "dig" yourself out of a huge hole. 

With multiple factions (each with some unique abilities), dozens of battle scenarios, multiplayer, Aeon Command is an interesting take on the space strategy genre with inspiration from old classic. If you value a simple and fast tactical strategy combat game, Aeon Command may scratch that itch. it's not complex, nor does it pretend to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049193268', 'num_games_owned': 819, 'num_reviews': 201, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1430003316}
review:
Voilà un petit RTS très sympa bien que basique. Un clic sur un bouton, un vaisseau est créé et part soit chercher des ressources soit attaquer l’ennemi selon son type. On ne contrôle pas les vaisseaux.

En général les parties commencent toujours par la création de 10 vaisseaux mineurs qui vont rapporter des ressources au vaisseau mère. Ensuite à vous de choisir… Attaquer l’ennemi tout de suite, ou attendre d’avoir beaucoup de ressources pour pouvoir attaquer avec plein de vaisseaux d’un coup ? Attaquer avec des petits vaisseaux ou des gros ? Ou encore améliorer vos vaisseaux avant d’attaquer ? La stratégie à appliquer varie selon les niveaux.

Pour varier les choses, la campagne est séparée en trois partie où on contrôle une race extraterrestre différente à chaque fois. Chacune dispose de ses propres vaisseaux et aptitudes.

À noter que le tuto est un peu confus, il peut être nécessaire de le refaire plusieurs fois avant de comprendre ce qu’on est censé faire. Quand un message ou un menu est affiché au milieu de l’écran, les ennemis continuent à attaquer !

Il m’a fallu environ 9h pour finir le jeu, donc à 3€ ça vaut le coup !

J’oubliais : pensez à retourner sur le menu principal pour améliorer vos vaisseaux et aptitudes après chaque niveau !

Testé sur Core i3/i5 + GTX 660, sous Arch Linux 64 bit.

PS: il y a une démo sur http://www.aeoncommand.com/ .

author: {'steamid': '76561197991466989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1202, 'last_played': 1648778812}
review:
Aeon Command is one of those games that's fun in small doses, and with its low price it's actually worth paying for those doses.  The graphics are certainly more than adequate to do the job, and the audio fits the art style and theme of gameplay.

The gameplay, however, won't win any awards for depth or breadth.  You spam numbers/clicks to build ships, use different keys/clicks to use special abilities, determine which ships to unlock and/or upgrade, and click on icons in the combat window to get resource, upgrade, or energy bonuses.

Likewise the campaign is nothing to write home about.  You get a set number of missions which each introduce a new ship or skill, do the same number of missions for each race, or game mode, and that's it.  The campaign is little more than a tutorial for skirmish games.

Skirmish, on the other hand, is where the game both shines and shows its worst flaw.  You get to play with all the races, all the game modes, all the range options, and even mix things up so that you and/or your enemy get a random assortment of ships and special abilities.  You could, for example, get the mining craft from race A which costs 8 resources to build (the others cost 10), a healer ship, a chain lightning ship, a railgun ship, and so on.  It will never randomly assign ships outside of their assigned slot so that you'll never get 2 or 3 ships normally in slot six, but it suffices to provide some variety in gameplay.  The game also provides three "difficulty" modes, and that is where the game's biggest flaw comes into play.

The AI cheats, at least on Hard difficulty.  It doesn't cheat by being "smarter" or by reacting faster to changes than a human can, nor do AI-controlled ships do any better when run by an AI player than a human.  Instead the developers opted to give the AI bonuses to resource acquisition.  Either it gets a steady stream of the crystals and energy or it gets a significant boost to how much it gets when it gets it.

This isn't a case of me being a bad player and blaming it on the game, nor is it a case of not understanding how the game works.  It's simply a matter of observing the facts.  When the AI is producing more ships than I can despite having the same number of collection ships out, and when the AI can use 55 energy skills/powers before I even have 1 energy, the AI is, in fact, cheating.  Edit:  I found a perfect example of the sort of benefits the AI gets over players.  As a player, I only get energy from killing enemy ships, but despite the AI having destroyed none of my ships it was able to pop off two EMPs and a Repair, total cost around 100 energy, at a time when I had only 17 energy, and this was less than four minutes into the game.

Over the course of half a dozen games against a Hard AI using the Cyborg race I had one of my first three combat ships mind controlled when I had 0 energy, the ship had just been produced, and while it was in range of my base ship and thus nowhere near enemy lines.  Furthermore, during my last play session I used Cheat Engine four times to bump my credits up by 1k, 1.5k, 2k, and 2.5k, and the first three were not enough to build and upgrade enough ships to give me a fighting chance.  It wasn't until I did the 2.5k bump that I had enough, and enough upgrades, to fight the AI with some degree of parity.  Eventually I won by spamming the slot 6 ship which, more often than not, can be an "I win" button for each race if you get a large enough swarm of them going.

This sort of cheating doesn't completely ruin gameplay, but it does make me want to avoid playing against Cyborgs or playing as Cyborgs on Hard.  Still, at $2.99 I'm more than willing to cut the developers some slack on shipping the game with a "difficulty" option that, at least for me, makes certain race/gameplay/side combinations absolute no-nos.  It's still something that should be considered if that sort of thing really irritates you.  The game is still quite fun up until Hard, and even on Hard as long as I play Human or Exile it's still quite enjoyable and winnable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067358822', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1688782599}
review:
Un juego que compré en una increíble rebaja de Steam. Inclusive, lo compré como prueba para ver si me era posible comprar juegos con lo que había ganado vendiendo cromos de juegos.

El juego es simple en un inicio. La mecánica de juego da mucho qué desear en un inicio. Los primeros minutos, hace pensar que es mas un juego demo sin mucho chiste. Tras comprender del todo las mecánicas y subir la dificultar a mas allá de "Normal", el juego se vuelve un verdadero reto.

La estrategia es realmente un componente clave, aún cuando no lo parezca. Comienzas con una única variedad de naves para producir, y para tener acceso a otras tienes que pagar (dinero que obtienes mientras avanza la partida). Al mismo tiempo, puedes mejorar tus naves (armas y escudos, mejoras que igualmente cuestan dinero). Las naves se despliegan tan pronto como las produces. Tu no controlas la acción, sólo tomas decisiones clave.

Un juego donde, realmente, en dificultad difícil, no es trivial ganar produciendo muchas naves de un mismo tipo. Realmente tienes que plantearte una estrategia. ¿Adquirir una nueva nave? Bien, pero eso retraza tu producción. ¿Que prefieres? ¿Producir más naves o mejorarlas? Un verdadero reto el que impone el juego.

La mecánica es sencilla, pero no se domina con facilidad.

Sin duda alguna lo recomiendo.
